data.title: Racketeer Rabbit (1946)
data.meta_description: Hugo and Rocky (caricatures of Edward G. Robinson and Peter Lorre) make it home to their hideout only to find Bugs already settled down there for the night.
data.text:
A quintessential example of the Freleng/Maltese Bugs Bunny: it's a pretty much nonstop gag machine, with the rascally rabbit's devious joy at making those who've wronged him suffer in penance fueling a huge array of jokes that hit the exact perfect sweet spot between weightlessly silly and psychologically cruel. But it's not so unrelenting that it's exhausting to watch, after the fashion of an Avery or Clampett gag machine. Hard to feel like that's a bad trade-off when you're right in front of the thing, watching the ingenious jokes pile up: Bugs having a huge handheld drill for quickly making rabbit holes which leads right to the gag of stars into the rabbit hole appearing out of nowhere, and later…

Friz is in peak form, baby! Very pretty colors, good layouts, and solid animation on a smaller, more wiry Bugs than his more humanoid appearances in the ‘50s. Still, it’s pretty amazing that this character is only a couple years old and is already so defined.

It’s very important to stress that even though Bugs is doing a lot of schtick (some that’s been done before in Tom Turk And Daffy, and some that Friz himself will emulate again in Bugsy and Mugsy), he is not annoying. He isn’t bouncing off the walls, and even if he is annoying our antagonists, it’s entertaining to us because it’s all very witty and well-orchestrated.

Our antagonists are funny enough, maybe funnier in…
